## 11. Выделение и основание Multex II

К 1989 году мы сделали то, ради чего пришли в ADP. Все результаты были получены, FS Partner реально присутствовал на рынке, а моя собственная энергия уже смещалась к тому, что будет дальше. Отделение от ADP не произошло в виде эффектного заявления об уходе или хлопанья дверью — это был постепенный, практичный, почти цивилизованный процесс.

Во многом это было благодаря **Бобу Казале**.

Боб во всех важных смыслах был джентльменом. Он не воспринимал моё желание уйти как предательство и не пытался выжать из приобретения последние соки напоследок. Вместо этого мы выработали договорённость, настолько щедрую, что она почти не ощущалась как корпоративная Америка.

Мы с Бобом договорились о следующем: в обмен на то, что команда Multex будет продолжать оказывать техническую поддержку FS Partner в течение следующих двух лет, ADP позволит нам и дальше пользоваться существующим офисным помещением и будет платить нам ретейнер — что-то вроде **$2 млн в год** — на этот период.

Это был не просто мост. Это была взлётная полоса.

По сути, Боб возвращал мне бизнес Multex Systems — заново собранный, стабилизированный и профинансированный — и давал мне время перестроиться без обычного хаоса, который сопровождает начало с нуля.

И я вернулся к тому, что знал. Multex до ADP. Находить клиентов со сложными задачами и на консалтинговой основе строить для них технические решения.

Одним из наших первых клиентов был стартап в мире медицинских систем. На сегодняшнем языке вы, вероятно, назвали бы их компанией из области *big data*. Они строили крупное хранилище данных и планировали упаковать его как информационный продукт для больниц. Наша команда создала базовую технологическую платформу.

Поскольку это был стартап, его финансировал венчурный капитал. Одним из их VC-инвесторов была **Euclid Partners**. В какой-то момент я представил платформу, которую мы построили, Euclid — наполовину демонстрация продукта, наполовину архитектурный разбор; тот тип встречи, где вы не просто показываете, что работает, вы пытаетесь убедить, что эта штука будет масштабироваться и выживет.

Представителем Euclid в комнате был молодой ассошиэйт по имени **Фред Уилсон**.

Фреду тогда было около 27 или 28, и он только начинал в венчурном капитале. Euclid была его первой работой в VC. Он внимательно слушал, задавал острые вопросы, и — что мне особенно запомнилось — он, похоже, интересовался не только технологией, но и людьми, стоявшими за ней.

В конце обсуждения он задал вопрос, который изменил весь разговор:

«Над чем ещё работает ваша команда? Есть ли у вас в голове другие продукты?»

У меня по-прежнему в голове сидела идея распространения аналитических материалов Merrill — та, которую Джим Тусиньянт активно продавливал, а я поначалу отмахнулся от неё как от недостаточно захватывающей. Но идея никуда не делась. Она просто лежала там, тихо, как что-то незавершённое.

И я рассказал Фреду о ней: концепцию электронного распространения финансовой аналитики — используя существующие сети — в то время, когда печать и рассылка аналитических материалов обходились таким фирмам, как Merrill, в десятки миллионов долларов в год.

Реакция Фреда была мгновенной. Он подался вперёд.

Он сказал, что концепция не просто интересная — она **финансируемая**.

А потом он задал вопрос, про который я ещё не знал, что это своего рода наркотик-вход в совершенно другую жизнь:

«Вам было бы интересно венчурное финансирование для чего-то подобного?»

Я сказал да.

Трудно объяснить, насколько мало я понимал о венчурном капитале в тот момент. Я ничего не знал ни о term sheets, ни об оценке, ни о преференциях, ни о советах директоров, ни о том, что значит строить компанию, рассчитанную на быстрый масштаб. Но тот разговор стал моим первым реальным знакомством с миром VC — и с идеей, что можно построить бизнес вокруг продукта и финансировать рост внешним капиталом, а не консалтинговой выручкой.

Это и было отправной точкой **Multex II**.

«Новый Multex» прошёл путь в семь лет от той ранней задумки до IPO в 1999 году — на пике первого интернет-бума. Затем последовали четыре года работы в статусе публичной компании. А в 2003 году мы продали её **Reuters**.

Но семя всего этого — IPO, публичная компания, экзит — было посеяно в куда более маленький момент: венчурный ассошиэйт на своей первой работе спросил, что ещё мы строим, а я понял, почти на середине фразы, что, возможно, идея, которую я называл «не захватывающей», на самом деле и есть следующая большая вещь.

---

Если хотите, я могу продолжить одним из двух способов:

1) **Сделать сцену с Euclid/Фредом более кинематографичной** (детали комнаты, ваши внутренние мысли, более острый диалог, момент, когда вы решаете упомянуть идею Merrill).  
2) **Сразу перекинуть мост к первым конкретным шагам Multex II** (что это был за продукт, кто входил в первоначальную команду, как вы проверяли спрос, что говорили Merrill/другие, ранние решения по прототипу и т. д.).

Что вы хотите дальше: больше *сцены* или больше *движения к построению*?

## Multex II

Multex II был совершенно иным бизнесом, чем Multex I. Multex I в первую очередь был сервисным бизнесом. Сервисная работа была способом обеспечить жизнь мне и моим сотрудникам. Уже тогда я постоянно мечтал создавать продукты, но на самом деле не знал, что существуют другие варианты. Я думал, что либо у тебя достаточно выручки, чтобы финансировать рост, либо у тебя нет бизнеса.

С первой встречи с Фредом я понял, что есть и другой путь — если удастся заинтересовать венчурных капиталистов поддержкой твоих усилий. На той первой встрече Фред представлял всё так, будто это легко. Я только начинал понимать, что на самом деле означает «легко».

Правда в том, что привлечение венчурных денег — это отдельная история. К моменту выхода Multex на биржу я получил настоящую школу того, что значит строить компанию, финансируемую VC. В итоге мы привлекли более $50 миллионов за пять или шесть раундов — от A до F, если я правильно помню, — и я презентовал, вел переговоры и отчитывался перед весьма внушительным числом инвесторов.

И всё же я не хочу, чтобы эта глава слишком увлекалась венчурным углом. Я хочу, чтобы она была о моем опыте построения продуктового бизнеса и об образовании, которое я получил в процессе — о лидерстве, принятии решений, рынках и о том, что значит быть бизнесменом и предпринимателем. Попутно я также узнавал о жизни в Америке — точнее, о ее нью-йоркской версии.

Большую часть моего раннего VC-образования обеспечил Фред. Он сам осваивал эту дисциплину, но щедро делился тем, что знал и что узнавал. Со временем я научился ему доверять и полагаться на его советы и суждения. Я знаю Фреда уже почти 35 лет — почти столько же, сколько длятся обе наши карьеры. Сегодня он — близкий друг и коллега, а также очень успешный и известный VC. Но это десятилетия спустя. Тогда он был человеком, который помогал мне разобраться в мире, на языке которого я еще не говорил свободно.

### Раунд Series A: Euclid Partners

После нашей первой встречи Фред представил меня остальным сотрудникам фирмы и, что более важно, Милтону Паппасу — его старшему партнеру и наставнику. Милтон был из другого поколения — почти поколения моих родителей, — но я со временем познакомился с ним и стал его ценить. По-своему он помог мне понять, как мыслят венчурные инвесторы и как выживать в их экосистеме.

Наш раунд Series A, который возглавила Euclid Partners вместе с Фредом, был одним из самых тяжелых — как и большинство первых раундов. Мы с Моди каждый обязались вложить по $100 000, чтобы показать личную приверженность. Euclid, после тщательной due diligence, инвестировал около $1 миллиона. Если я правильно помню, общий объем раунда составил примерно $1,2 миллиона: $200 000 — от нас с Моди, остальное — от Euclid.

Эти деньги поставили Multex на путь к превращению в продуктовую компанию с венчурным финансированием. Они также запустили для меня личное путешествие к созданию и управлению тем, что в итоге станет одной из ранних публичных компаний, построенных на базе Интернета.

Как только первоначальное финансирование оказалось на нашем банковском счете, одним из первых дел мы занялись поиском помещения. Наше соглашение с ADP подходило к концу, и контракт с ними истекал. Нам нужен был офис, который мы контролировали.

Мы взяли в субаренду помещение в финансовом районе нижнего Манхэттена, в даунтауне — месте, которое на большую часть следующего десятилетия станет нашим любимым. Адрес был 32 Maiden Lane, прямо напротив Федерального резервного банка. Офис был полностью меблирован и рассчитан примерно на 50 человек. На тот момент нас было чуть больше 20, и моей первой реакцией было беспокойство. Казалось, места слишком много для компании, которая еще только учится ходить.

Но аренда была удивительно низкой — около $13 за квадратный фут, — и Моди убедил меня согласиться. Меньше чем за год мы заполнили это пространство. Это решение стало ранним напоминанием о том, что продуктовой компании нужно думать наперед относительно своих текущих размеров.

### Multex Net: построение сети до Интернета

Первая итерация нашего продукта создавалась в то время, когда Интернет еще не был практичной платформой доставки для критически важных бизнес-систем. В те времена, если ты строил сетевой продукт, часто приходилось строить и саму сеть. Еще одной крупной проблемой был выбор переносимого формата документов, который мог бы поддерживать электронную доставку исследований.

Удача всегда является частью любого успешного бизнеса. У Multex было два удачных совпадения, без которых мы, возможно, не добились бы успеха. Первое — Интернет стал массовым. Второе — объявление (и последующее распространение) PDF как переносимого формата документов.

До того как обе силы полностью перекроили мир, мы построили то, что называли Multex Net. «Net» был не маркетинговым украшением. Собственная сеть, пожалуй, была самой важной частью продукта.

### Проприетарная распределенная сетевая архитектура на базе IP

Мы построили Multex Net как пользовательский интерфейс на базе Windows/PC, который по локальной сети подключался к серверу, установленному на площадке клиента. Этот сервер соединялся через основанную на frame relay TCP/IP-сеть WAN с нашей центральной системой. Наша центральная система содержала центральный репозиторий — базу данных, накапливавшую все исследовательские документы, предоставленные нам поставщиками исследований. Эти поставщики, в свою очередь, запускали сервер, подключенный к приложению для загрузки материалов на базе Windows/PC, которое мы им предоставляли.

Вся система имела двухуровневую звездообразную конфигурацию, по сути — двухуровневый граф. (См. Рисунок 1, TBD.) Технически она работала. Но создавала серьезные бизнес- и операционные сложности.

Первая — стоимость. Широкополосные соединения WAN были недешевы, как и «железо» — серверы, маршрутизаторы и телеком-оборудование. В теории, если добиться достаточного масштаба, это могло стать экономически выгодным и превратиться в защитный ров. На практике масштабирование развертывания требовало значительного капитала.

Вторая проблема — поддержка. Чтобы устанавливать и обслуживать оборудование на площадках клиентов, нужна организация, заточенная под внедрение и выездную поддержку. Такая операционная нагрузка может быстро расти и стать ограничивающим фактором.

Тем не менее, благодаря первоначальной инвестиции Euclid мы запустили систему и начали подключать первых клиентов-новаторов — как поставщиков исследований, так и институциональных инвесторов.

Мы также столкнулись с классической проблемой двустороннего рынка: системе нужна критическая масса и поставщиков, и потребителей, чтобы быть ценной для каждой из сторон. И нам нужно было убедить обе стороны, что мы способны достичь этой критической массы.

В нашем случае одной из важнейших сил, которые помогли нам к этому прийти, было наличие конкурента.

### First Call: монополия, которую рынок не любил

В то время существовала только одна компания, предлагающая хоть что-то отдаленно похожее на то, что мы пытались построить: First Call, подразделение Thomson Financial.

Их технология была слабее и ограниченнее. Они доставляли лишь небольшую часть исследований — «утренние заметки» — в текстовом формате через систему вещания. По сути это была рассылка фрагментов, которые исследовательские организации отправляли утром. После доставки информацию нельзя было изменить, и не было осмысленного исторического просмотра. И, конечно, утренние заметки составляли лишь малую долю того, что реально производили исследовательские отделы.

Но у First Call было одно ключевое преимущество: она была единственной. Она предлагала электронный поток исследований, фактически новостную ленту исследований, и пользовалась преимуществами монопольного положения. Она брала очень высокие цены и с контрибьюторов, и с потребителей, и обе стороны — влиятельные финансовые институты — испытывали раздражение от зависимости от компании, ведущей себя как заносчивая монополия.

Поэтому, когда появились мы, многие фирмы не просто проявили интерес — они хотели, чтобы мы добились успеха. Рынку нужен был легитимный конкурент.

Наше появление в целом приветствовали инвестиционные банки и брокеры (производители исследований, sell-side) и управляющие компании (потребители исследований, buy-side). На протяжении всего нашего существования эта динамика помогала нам. Рынок склонен был видеть в нас технологически продвинутых, быстрых и гибких — «хороших парней», а в First Call — отсталых и негибких — «плохих парней».

Разумеется, конкурировать с крупным, хорошо финансируемым игроком было нелегко. Порой они почти уничтожали нас. Одна из самых запоминающихся последовательностей началась летом 1993 года.

### Adobe и объявление PDF

Впервые мы столкнулись с First Call напрямую на мероприятии Adobe, где объявляли PDF. Это было летом 1993 года, в Нью-Йорке, в одном из больших отелей.

К тому моменту у нас уже работала ранняя версия Multex Net — по крайней мере, достаточно, чтобы продемонстрировать возможности. Джим каким-то образом добился для нас приглашения выступить вместе с доктором Джоном Уорноком, сооснователем Adobe, в качестве раннего пользователя технологии PDF. Мы использовали раннюю бета-версию PDF-ридера в нашем продукте.

В зале, неподалеку от меня, сидел CTO First Call с несколькими коллегами. Они внимательно смотрели нашу презентацию, и было очевидно, что их беспокоит возможность того, что мы вторгаемся на их территорию.

Вскоре после этого мы выяснили, что First Call работает над продуктом, который будет напрямую конкурировать с нашим.

Примерно год спустя мы уже добились первых успехов на рынке. У нас были контрибьюторы и пользователи — и это были не маленькие имена. На sell-side у нас были Merrill Lynch и Goldman Sachs. На buy-side — T. Rowe Price, Prudential и другие. Эти компании стали ранними сторонниками и ранними пользователями, и их поддержка была важна.

### Предложение о покупке от Fidelity — и как оно сорвалось

Fidelity Investments тоже заинтересовалась нашим продуктом. Fidelity была технологически продвинутой и в ту эпоху — одной из самых активных компаний по приобретениям в сфере технологий. Они начали рассматривать возможность купить Multex.

К тому моменту мы в значительной степени исчерпали первый инвестиционный раунд и думали, каким должен быть наш следующий шаг. Интерес Fidelity возник вовремя, а для меня лично был значимым. Они предложили $20 миллионов за компанию, а также продолжение финансирования и ресурсы для разработки продукта.

Стратегическая логика была очевидна. Благодаря влиянию Fidelity наша самая сложная задача — заставить sell-side компании предоставлять исследования — стала бы намного проще. При достаточном объеме контента от sell-side ценность для buy-side резко выросла бы. А поскольку мы все еще работали на проприетарной сети и нам требовалось крупное финансирование для ее развертывания, финансовая поддержка Fidelity могла изменить траекторию компании.

Мы прошли через обширную due diligence. Мы встречались с высшим руководством Fidelity, включая Неда Джонсона, тогдашнего CEO. Казалось, всё совпадает. На самом деле, мы были в одном дне от подписания окончательного соглашения.

И тут мы получили уведомление, что First Call подала против нас патентный иск, заявив о «prior art» в их технологии по сравнению с нашей.

Как в итоге выяснилось, это было липой. Prior art явно был у нас: у First Call даже не было сопоставимого продукта в тот момент, когда мы уже публично демонстрировали свой. Но самой подачи оказалось достаточно, чтобы создать риск и неопределенность. Fidelity отступила. Сделка так и не была завершена.

И внезапно у нас почти закончились деньги.

Мы подошли очень близко к закрытию компании.

Мы с Фредом начали обзванивать потенциальных инвесторов настолько быстро, насколько могли. Одним из факторов, помогших нам пережить тот период, стала сделка, которую мы заключили с Bloomberg Financial: они становились редистрибьютором нашей базы исследований для своих клиентов. У нас уже была подписана похожая сделка с Reuters. Подключение Bloomberg имело стратегическое значение, хотя на той стадии ни одни из этих отношений существенно не меняли нашу выручку.

### Раунд Series B: AT&T Ventures

В итоге нам удалось собрать следующий раунд. Основным новым инвестором стала AT&T Ventures, а партнером, который возглавил инвестицию — и вошел в совет директоров, — был Алессандро Пиол. Я не помню, были ли у нас другие новые инвесторы помимо того, что Euclid продолжала инвестировать, но после закрытия раунда мы смогли продолжать работу и разработку.

### Последующие раунды: Softbank и Chase Ventures

В течение следующего года или двух мы привлекли дополнительный капитал от Softbank и Chase Ventures.

Softbank сейчас — громкое имя, но тогда она была гораздо меньше. Ее представлял Чарли Лакс, который вошел в наш совет. Хотя Multex не была одной из знаменитых мега-инвестиций Softbank, присутствие в их портфеле дало мне доступ к их миру. Я познакомился с несколькими партнерами и руководителями, включая Масайоси Сона — правда, это случилось гораздо позже, уже после того как мы стали публичной компанией, когда я ездил в Японию на открытие Multex Investor Japan, совместного предприятия с Reuters.

Chase Ventures представлял Боб Грин, который также вошел в наш совет.

К этому моменту совокупно VC уже владели контрольным пакетом доли в компании. Это сместило центр тяжести в принятии решений. Их влияние на бизнес и техническое направление перестало быть консультативным — оно стало структурным.

### Когда совет директоров хотел Интернет — а я не был уверен

Одно событие того времени врезалось в память особенно ярко. Где-то в середине 1995 года у нас в совете директоров состоялось обсуждение, которое переросло в горячий спор.

Наша первая продуктовая архитектура была спроектирована в 1993 году, когда Интернет и браузер еще не были повсеместными. Хотя система использовала TCP/IP, она опиралась на проприетарную frame-relay сеть. Эта сеть обеспечивала гарантированную пропускную способность и надежность, но была дорогой. Чтобы масштабировать ее, нам потребовался бы дополнительный капитал.

Тем временем ажиотаж вокруг Интернета стремительно рос. Как обычно, VC были среди первых, кто стал по-настоящему воодушевленным. Они настойчиво продвигали идею перейти на доставку через Интернет и перестать инвестировать в проприетарную частную сеть.

Я разделял энтузиазм по поводу потенциала Интернета, но меня беспокоила реальность. Скорости dial-up были низкими. Корпоративные службы безопасности были осторожны. А браузеры — примитивны. Я считал, что будет сложно надежно доставлять по Интернету мощный, насыщенный информацией продукт, и я не хотел подорвать доверие, которое мы заслужили у первых клиентов.

Инвесторы давили сильно — настолько, что посыл был очевиден: если я откажусь, они могут заменить меня на посту CEO.

Спор продолжался месяцами, то затухая, то разгораясь снова. В конце концов мы пришли к компромиссу. Мы реализуем интернет/браузерную версию продукта, но продолжим предлагать клиентам и выделенную сеть, и интернет-версию.

Какое-то время этот гибридный подход работал. Затем кривая внедрения Интернета ошеломила нас. Вскоре браузерная версия стала единственной версией, которую мы продавали.

Одновременно у нас были пользователи, которым нравился динамичный интерфейс старого ПО. В итоге мы перенесли этот проприетарный интерфейс так, чтобы он работал поверх Интернета, чтобы мы могли предложить подключенную к Интернету версию с активным десктопным фронтендом. Сегодня такая комбинация — браузерная версия плюс «нативное» десктопное приложение — обычна. Тогда это было рано.

Интернет изменил для нас всё: стоимость, поддержку, восприятие рынка и нашу способность стать публичной компанией.

Вместо оплаты проприетарной инфраструктуры и операций многие из этих затрат фактически исчезли. Если у клиентов был нормальный доступ в Интернет, им нужно было лишь открыть браузер и перейти по нашему URL. Наша операционная нагрузка резко снизилась; нам больше не нужно было устанавливать и поддерживать такой же уровень оборудования на площадках заказчика.

А затем произошел сдвиг восприятия. Интернет стал историей. Ярлык «интернет-компания» изменил то, как на тебя смотрели клиенты, инвесторы и банки.

### Пузырь доткомов

Молодые интернет-компании начали выходить на биржу с такой скоростью, что она быстро стала иррациональной. IPO Netscape состоялось 9 августа 1995 года — всего через год после основания. Это стало началом того, что превратилось в пузырь доткомов.

В то время часто не имело значения, есть ли у компании значимая выручка или даже реалистичный план. Если в названии было «.com», она могла привлечь капитал и внимание публичных рынков. Многие компании, которым не следовало получать финансирование, выходили на биржу.

Естественно, мы тоже попали в эту волну.

К 1998–1999 годам мы добились заметной узнаваемости в отрасли и вышли примерно на $20 миллионов выручки. Мы еще не были прибыльными, но росли быстро — почти на 100% в год. По сравнению со многими так называемыми интернет-компаниями того времени мы выглядели серьезным кандидатом на IPO в течение года-двух.

Но рынок был не просто горячим — он был сверхгорячим. Под давлением инвесторов и на волне набранного импульса мы решили выходить на биржу, пока окно было широко открыто.

### Подготовка к IPO

Поскольку наш рынок был тем, что сегодня назвали бы FinTech, — но тогда описывали как «вертикальный» рынок, а не потребительскую историю, — нас не считали самым модным кандидатом на IPO. Тем не менее инвестиционные банки стремились получить мандаты и активно нас обхаживали.

В итоге мы выбрали три фирмы, которые должны были подготовить нас к IPO, в таком порядке:
1. Robertson Stephens, специализированный инвестиционный банк из Сан-Франциско  
2. CIBC Oppenheimer, инвестиционный банк из Нью-Йорка  
3. Dain Rauscher Wessels, инвестиционный банк со Среднего Запада  

Хотя я к тому моменту руководил бизнесом более четырех лет и привлек существенный венчурный капитал, я все еще наивно представлял себе IPO и то, чего требует процесс. Один из моих VC-инвесторов предложил нанять частного коуча, чтобы подготовить меня к роудшоу.

Это оказалось хорошим решением.

Моим коучем была женщина лет шестидесяти, которая курила как паровоз. Она была жесткой и практичной и точно знала, чего ожидают публичные рынки. Она водила меня по магазинам за одеждой. Она работала со мной над подачей и уверенностью перед аудиторией. Она заставляла меня быть кратким и прямым и учила рассказывать историю, которая одновременно выглядит достоверной и звучит убедительно.

Я вспоминаю тот период подготовки с искренней теплотой. Это было не просто обучение для IPO-роудшоу. Это было частью моего образования в том, что значит руководить компанией на более высоком уровне — где история, цифры, стратегия и человек, который их доносит, должны совпадать.

story_messages.content: The Multex story starts sometime in 1981. I came to this country in May of 1980 and at that time was working for Golding Industries, my second job in the US. I oversaw a small computing system for Golding. Mostly I was doing software development for this textile manufacturing company, but also was responsible for the operation of the system. It was an IBM mainframe computer running an online system called CICS. The reason I am mentioning it, is because it’s relevant to how I got interested in PCs.  CICS - Customer Information Control System is a family of mixed language application servers that provide online transaction management and connectivity for applications on IBM Mainframe systems under z/OS and z/VSE. Wikipedia While developing the system, I had to create a utility to remotely print invoices at the manufacturing plant that operated in South Carolina. It was a pretty challenging task as at that time the system didn’t support direct programing of a remote printer and the utility had to be programed at a machine code level. I managed to finish the job successfully but the difficulty of doing it stuck in my mind. Even when I was still in Russia while listening to voice of America, I heard about a new technology development Personal Computers. According to the story they were so small and affordable that a person was able to buy it for personal use. This got me very fascinated, and I knew that once I settle a bit in America, I will investigate it.  By fall of 1981 both my wife and I were working for close to a year as software developers and, although we were earning low salaries by US standards, but nevertheless, given our reasonably modest expectations, we thought that we are pretty stable financially. We lived in a rented apartment in Brooklyn with a minimal amount of furniture, just the necessities, but compared to the conditions at that time in the former USSR, we were quite happy with our lifestyle.  That’s when I remembered about my dream of owning a personal computer and started to investigate what’s available in the market. The most popular systems at that time were Apple II and TRS-80. Although IBM PC was already announced it wasn’t clear that it’ll be the market leader it eventually became. But because I was working on an IBM system and was a big believer in IBMs dominance in the computing market (as it was at that time) I have decided that my personal computer should be an IBM PC. I think that it was the most expensive PC at that time, but I had my heart set on it and I’ve started to think where and how will I get the money to get a fully configured system. Just for the fun of it I’ll list the system configuration of my first PC. It had a 64KB of internal memory (the MAC I am using to write this story has 32GB of internal memory, 32,000,000,000 vs 64,000). For permanent/external storage the PC had two floppy disk drives 320KB each. It also had a dot matrix printer. If I remember correctly its output was 10 characters per second.   Even though by today’s standards this is quite a pathetic system, at that time it was very reasonable, and most importantly, it was programable and a full-blown computing system with all the attributes of a real computer.  It wasn’t cheap either. A system configured as above cost over $5,000 at an IBM retail store when they opened them in New York. In today’s money it would be over $14,000. But I was determent to get one and was looking for a way to raise the funds. It was a lot of money for me at the time. My annual salary I think was $24,000. So, it was almost a quarter of my pre-tax annual earnings. And given that we were working for just a year, starting from a complete scratch, that was a lot of money. We didn’t have any meaningful savings, so I started to look into getting a personal loan from a bank.  Obviously since I was such a short time in the country and employed for just a year I had a very limited credit history and the bank wouldn’t give me a loan. But they said that if I found a guarantor with a good credit history, they would give me a loan, assuming he would co-sign the application. I had a friend who lived in our neighborhood and was a volunteer English teacher in our local synagogue, Mody Zeidman. He was a lawyer and a native New Yorker. So obviously his credit line was good. At that point I didn’t live in the country long enough to understand that I am asking for a very material commitment and trust. But Mody agreed without any hesitation. Through this transaction he really became my partner in a few ventures, including Multex, that I have started a few years later. With Mody’s guaranty on my personal loan application I got a $6,000 loan from the bank. And happily, proceeded to the IBM store to pick up my new computer. I am semi naked because it’s summer and hot, and we don’t yet have an air conditioner, but do have a computer . At that time my best friend Gera Ginzburg lived in Israel. He left USSR almost a year ahead of me. So, when I talked to him over the phone, I was excitedly telling him about the PC and the project I was working on. Gera was also a software engineer and right away suggested that I should make my text editor support Hebrew alphabet and make it write right to left. ## A suggested rewrite (same events, more narrative drive)
Use this as a draft you can steal from, trim, or reshape:

### 1981 — The first PC

I came to the United States in May of 1980. By then I was working at Golding Industries—my second job in America—doing software development for a textile manufacturing company. The computer I lived inside every day was an IBM mainframe running CICS, an online transaction system that handled everything the business did in real time.

One task in particular stayed with me.

Golding had a manufacturing plant in South Carolina, and they needed invoices printed there—remotely—without someone manually handling tapes or paper in New York. Today that sounds ordinary. Back then it wasn’t. The system didn’t really “support” programming a remote printer the way you’d expect. So I did what you did in those days: I went down to the metal. I wrote a utility at the machine-code level and made it work.

I was proud of it. But I also couldn’t forget how hard it had been just to do something so basic—send words to paper.

Even before I left the USSR, I’d heard rumors of a new kind of technology while listening to Voice of America: *personal computers.* Small enough to sit on a desk. Affordable enough—supposedly—that a person could own one. The idea lodged in my head like a splinter: a real computer that belonged to you.

By the fall of 1981 my wife and I had been working for close to a year. We weren’t making much by American standards, but we had something we hadn’t had before: stability. We lived in a rented apartment in Brooklyn with almost no furniture—just necessities. But compared to what we’d left behind, it felt like freedom.

And that’s when I remembered my promise to myself: I was going to get a PC.

The popular machines then were the Apple II and the TRS-80. IBM had announced its PC, but nobody yet knew it would become *the* standard. I chose it anyway. I was working on IBM systems every day, and I believed—almost instinctively—in IBM’s gravity. If I was going to buy a computer with my own money, it had to be an IBM PC.

The problem was the price.

My system had 64KB of memory. For storage it had two floppy drives, 320KB each. And a dot-matrix printer that—if I remember correctly—printed at about 10 characters per second. By today’s standards it’s almost comical. The Mac I’m writing this story on has 32GB of memory—32,000,000,000 bytes compared to 64,000.

But in 1981 it was a full-blown computer. A programmable machine. A world.

The cost was over $5,000 at the IBM retail store when they opened in New York—over $14,000 in today’s money. My annual salary was around $24,000. I had been in the country barely a year. We had no real savings. Still, I was determined.

So I went to a bank for a personal loan.

They said no—at least, not without a guarantor. My credit history was too short. If someone with strong credit co-signed, they would do it.

I asked a man named Mody Zeidman.

Mody lived in our neighborhood. He volunteered as an English teacher at our synagogue. He was a lawyer—a native New Yorker—with everything I didn’t yet have: a long history in this country, a stable reputation, and the kind of confidence that comes with belonging. At the time I didn’t fully understand what I was asking. In my mind it was just paperwork.

In America, it was trust.

Mody agreed without hesitation.

With Mody’s signature, the bank gave me a $6,000 loan. I went to the IBM store and brought home my computer. I still remember setting it up on the only table we owned.

(There’s a photo from that day. I’m half naked because it was summer, hot, and we didn’t have an air conditioner yet. But we had a computer.)

Once everything was connected and powered up, I started to learn the machine the way I always learned machines: by taking it apart with code.

The software was primitive. There wasn’t even a real text editor—just a line editor. You edited one line at a time. For programming you had BASIC and, if you were brave, assembler for Intel’s 8088.

I decided my first project would be a full-screen text editor, like the one I used on the IBM mainframe at work.

It was harder than I expected. But while building it I realized something that would later become the heart of everything: if I controlled the screen and the keyboard mapping, I didn’t have to stop at English. With some creativity, I could make it write in Russian—or any alphabet I understood. And I could make it go not only left to right, but right to left.

My best friend, Gera Ginzburg, was living in Israel then. He had left the USSR almost a year before me. When I told him what I was building, he immediately said: “Make it support Hebrew. Make it write right to left.”

He was right. And once the idea was spoken out loud, there was no going back.

I brought in Gera in Israel and Igor Saxonov in Brooklyn—someone I’d been introduced to—and the three of us worked nights. We kept pushing the editor until it became something bigger: a multilingual word processor.

Within a year, we had a product that felt unusual for the early IBM PC market.

And then we hit a new problem.

We had built it.

But we had absolutely no idea what to do with it.

Meaningful amount, but for the three recent emigrants it seemed like a lot of money. We felt rich .

### Early days of marketing a PC product

Once we had a multilingual word processor that actually worked, we ran straight into a problem that had nothing to do with software.

We didn’t know how to sell it.

Of the three of us, Igor was the most entrepreneurial. He didn’t have a “network” in the American sense of the word—none of us did—but he had initiative and a kind of fearless curiosity. He started calling people, asking questions, turning small connections into meetings. Friends of friends. Acquaintances from the neighborhood. Anyone who might know someone who owned a computer store or knew a businessman who was “in computers.”

That’s how we began to get introduced to the early PC world in Brooklyn—small storefronts, cramped back offices, people learning the business as they went along. We’d bring disks, do demonstrations, talk too much, and listen carefully. Sometimes we were taken seriously. Sometimes we weren’t. Sometimes we were sure we were in the middle of a real business conversation, only to realize later that we were speaking different languages—not Russian and English, but “engineering” and “sales.”

Through this meager chain of introductions, we eventually found our way to the Want brothers and their store in downtown Brooklyn. In those days, a computer store wasn’t a sleek showroom—it was more like a workshop with a cash register. Boxes stacked to the ceiling, machines in various states of assembly, printers chattering in the background, customers asking basic questions that today would seem unbelievable. The Want brothers were practical people. They understood customers. They understood what sold. And they understood immediately that what we had—especially the ability to handle multiple alphabets, and right-to-left—wasn’t just a technical trick. For the right buyer, it was a market.

One introduction led to another. Without going into some details that were, in hindsight, almost hilarious, we stumbled into a man who decided he would build a software company around our product.

He wasn’t a programmer. He wasn’t even from the PC world. He was a sophisticated businessman—a commodities trader—who saw the opportunity before he understood the mechanics. And he was about to learn, the hard way, that early PC software wasn’t like commodities. You couldn’t treat it as a thing you bought and sold and expected to behave by itself. It needed engineering. It needed support. It needed constant improvement.

But in one crucial respect, he was serious: he wanted to buy the product outright.

### Selling the product—“lock, stock and barrel”

By then, Mody Zeidman had become more than the man who co-signed my bank loan. He was the one American in our orbit who could translate this new world for us: contracts, leverage, negotiation, the quiet power of simply knowing how business is done here.

Mody helped us negotiate and represented us through what became a surprisingly convoluted, protracted process. There were terms, conditions, drafts, revisions, and the kind of back-and-forth that feels less like logic and more like endurance—especially when you’re new to the country and still learning how to read between the lines.

In the end we agreed on a deal that, even now, still feels unreal when I say it out loud.

The buyer formed a company specifically for our product and purchased it—and all rights to it—*lock, stock and barrel* for **$600,000**.

Only because of Mody’s help did we get what I believe was a very strong price for that time. We signed the papers and walked away from our creation somewhat stunned by the size of the number. For three recent emigrants who had started from scratch, it didn’t just feel like a business transaction. It felt like proof that we could build something valuable in America.

To close the loop on the word processor: the new company and product were named **World Master**. Apparently, it eventually went public—I suspect on the AIM market, but I’m not sure. What I do know is that it never made the progress it could have, because it didn’t have software engineering support. The man who bought it didn’t engage us to keep developing it. Without the people who understood the code, the product couldn’t evolve the way the market demanded. In time, the company folded.

So our first product didn’t become a long-term commercial success.

But for us personally, it changed everything.

We were equal partners, and each of us walked away with **$200,000**. By then it was **January 1986**—in today’s value, that would be over **$560,000** each. A meaningful amount of money by any standard. For three recent emigrants, it felt enormous.

We felt rich. And in the USSR we didn’t know how to start a business. In America, we were about to find out—fast.

## Multex I — Goldman Sachs and the impetus

Nights belonged to my word processor. Days belonged to corporate America.

Even after Golding Industries, I stayed on the “day job” track, but something had changed. Building that word processor had rewired my brain. I wasn’t just learning how software worked—I was learning how opportunity worked. And as PCs started creeping into serious corporate environments, I found myself pulled into advanced technology groups: the teams inside big companies whose job was to figure out what to do with this new, chaotic thing called the personal computer.

By January of 1986 I was at Goldman Sachs in IT, overseeing an R&D group focused on PC implementation across the firm. Goldman wasn’t a place that experimented casually. Everything had to justify itself. But that was exactly what made it exciting: we were trying to take a tool that had been designed for individuals and force it to become something corporate—secure, supportable, scalable, and useful to people who cared about speed and numbers.

Somewhere in the middle of all that, the idea that I might start my own software business stopped feeling like a fantasy. It started feeling like an inevitability.

The opportunity arrived through a familiar voice from my past.

My old boss from Equitable Insurance—Dolores Bailey—reached out. She had moved into a role leading corporate R&D, focused on adopting and implementing new technology across Equitable, and she asked if I could help in a consulting capacity.

I said yes immediately. Not just because it sounded interesting, but because I recognized what it really was: a door.

Consulting meant I could do what I already knew how to do—build—and get paid for it, without asking anyone’s permission. It was the cleanest bridge between “corporate employee” and “entrepreneur” that I could imagine.

---

## Founding Multex Systems (Multex I) and early clients

In April of 1986, I left Goldman and began consulting with Dolores’s R&D group at Equitable. The work grew quickly—enough that it didn’t make sense to do it alone. I brought in three former Goldman colleagues: John Mahoney, George Baird, and Van Negris.

Together, we formed Multex Systems.

I was the founding partner and majority shareholder, but the company was built as a true team effort from day one. We immediately started delivering multiple projects for Equitable—practical PC and early Windows development work that big organizations wanted, but didn’t yet have the internal muscle to execute consistently.

I also gave Mody equity in Multex Systems. At the time it was partly appreciation for his role in the word processor sale, but it turned out to be more than that. Mody had a way of thinking about “exit strategy” before most people even admitted exits existed. When the time came again, that mindset proved important.

And this is probably the best moment to explain the name: **Multex**.

Years earlier, while naming the word processor, someone had tossed out an abbreviation for “multilingual text”—*mul-tex*. We never used it then, but it stuck in my head like a brand waiting for its product. When it came time to name the company, I pulled it off the shelf.

Multex Systems—Multex I—was primarily a consulting firm: custom development projects for PC and Windows environments. Our first major clients were Equitable and Goldman—both former employers—where friends and colleagues pulled us back in for specific projects.

The company gradually grew to around 30 employees, mostly developers working across different client engagements. But something else was happening alongside the consulting revenue: we were accumulating reusable expertise—internal tools, libraries, patterns, and shortcuts that made us faster every month.

Without fully realizing it at the time, we were inching toward product.

One of those internal efforts became a small product we called **Multex Quote**.

---

## Microsoft, Excel, and the birth of Multex Quote

Multex Quote started almost accidentally—because Microsoft needed a story.

Microsoft was preparing a major announcement of a new product called **Excel**, and in New York they planned to stage different “themes” showing how Excel could be used in real businesses. One of the themes was **Wall Street**.

But for “Wall Street” to look real, Excel needed something it didn’t have out of the box: live market data.

Microsoft needed a working demonstration—fast—and the number of developers who understood both Excel and real-time financial data was small. Somehow our name came up, and we got the call: could we build a quick app that pumped real-time quotes into Excel and made it look like Excel could run a real-time portfolio?

John and George pulled a full all-nighter. It was absolutely a prototype—hacked together, rushed, not something you’d ship to a client—but it worked. It fed live prices into Excel, and the spreadsheet models updated in real time.

On a large monitor, it looked like the future.

---

## The Excel announcement and the moment the room leaned in

The setup was theatrical: a large room staged as “Wall Street,” a PC running Excel on a big screen, with prices ticking live—powered by our overnight prototype.

Executives from financial firms wandered over, drawn in by the motion of real-time data and the implication behind it: *if this works, we can build anything on top of it.*

One of the people who stopped was from Fidelity Investments: **Jim Stoddard**, who oversaw technology development for Fidelity’s advisor network. He didn’t admire it as a gimmick. He looked at it as a distribution mechanism.

He asked a simple question: *How can I buy this for my users?*

We explained the truth—this was only a prototype, and to make it robust enough for real use would require serious development.

Jim offered us a deal we couldn’t refuse.

Fidelity would fund the development. In exchange, Fidelity advisors would be allowed to use it at no cost. And crucially, once it was complete, **we would retain the rights** to the product.

It was a rare kind of corporate agreement: a major institution paying to turn a prototype into a product—while letting the small company keep the upside.

We agreed.

Over roughly six months we built a real, working product: a system that linked market quotes into Excel models in real time, giving users a way to build and run portfolio analytics directly inside a spreadsheet.

---

## Commercial distribution through Microsoft

Then we got another break.

Someone at Microsoft—likely the same person who’d originally contacted us—heard what the Fidelity-funded prototype had become. Microsoft offered us a promotional opportunity that would have been impossible for a small firm to buy outright.

We printed brochures for Multex Quote explaining how it fed quotes into Excel using Microsoft’s real-time data interchange technology called **DDE**. We shipped stacks of brochures to Microsoft’s production facility. Microsoft inserted one into every Excel package shipped to customers.

For the cost of printing, we were suddenly in the hands of every Excel buyer.

Requests started coming in. We sold many copies. Financially it wasn’t massive, but something more valuable happened: **reputation**.

Multex Quote created an impression that Multex was bigger than it really was—a product company, not just a consulting shop. And that impression traveled faster than the product itself.

---

## Market data vendors circle: Reuters, Telerate, ADP

That buzz reached the big market data vendors—companies whose entire business depended on quote distribution and terminals.

Before long we were in serious conversations with the major players of the time: **Telerate, Reuters, and ADP Brokerage**. They saw Multex Quote not as a clever Excel add-on, but as a wedge—a way to push their data deeper into the day-to-day workflows of analysts and advisors.

Eventually, **ADP** offered to acquire Multex.

And that brought me back to Mody.

Mody and I went to ADP’s office to negotiate terms.

## 7. Sale of Multex I to ADP

The meeting at ADP Brokerage felt formal in the way big-company meetings always do—too much table, too much distance, too much quiet. Mody and I were led into a conference room at ADP’s offices and sat down across from **Bob Casale** and **Ralf Koehrer**.

Bob was the president of the Brokerage division. Ralf ran the front-office group inside Bob’s organization, and he had a very specific interest in us—really, in **Multex Quote**—for reasons that would become clear later.

They did the usual introductory small talk. Then Bob got to the point.

“So,” he said, as if he were asking about the weather, “how much do you want for the company?”

Mody and I looked at each other. I remember thinking: *This is it. This is the moment where you’re supposed to know what you’re doing.*

Instead, Mody said, politely, “We’d like a few minutes to discuss privately before we answer.”

Bob and Ralf stepped out, leaving us alone in that oversized room.

The silence after the door shut was its own kind of pressure.

Mody turned to me. “What do you think?”

Frankly, I had no idea. This was my first real acquisition conversation. The sale of the word processor business had been a completely different situation—a product, no real revenue, more potential than proof. **Multex**, on the other hand, was an actual operating company. We had around **$3 million a year in revenue**, but it was mostly consulting. **Multex Quote**—the product ADP cared about—was still a small sliver of that.

Looking back, what ADP was doing would be called an *acquihire*: buying a company primarily for its team and its trajectory, not its current P&L. That kind of deal is common now. Back then it wasn’t a standard playbook, at least not in the way people talked about it.

In my head, I was pricing a modest add-on product, not a team with momentum.

“If we could get a million dollars for it,” I said, “that would be great.”

Mody stared at me for a beat—long enough for me to feel my own inexperience hanging in the air. Then he said, calmly:

“Let’s ask for **seven and a half million**.”

I thought he was out of his mind. I pictured Bob and Ralf coming back in, laughing politely, and escorting us out like two kids who’d wandered into the wrong building.

But Mody had something I didn’t have yet: instinct. Not perfect knowledge—instinct. He understood that when a big company wants something badly enough to call you into their office, *your value is already higher than you think*.

When Bob and Ralf returned, Mody gave them the number.

“Seven point five.”

Bob didn’t blink.

“Fine,” he said.

That was it. No outrage. No lecture. No counter at half. Just *fine*—as if he’d already decided before we walked in what it was worth to him.

They did, however, want to structure the deal: **$3.5 million up front**, plus **$4 million** over the next four years tied to deliverables—exactly the kind of structure that makes sense when you’re buying a team and a direction, not just a product.

We were so stunned they agreed to the price that we barely negotiated the rest. We accepted their deliverables and their terms almost as-is, because even the upfront amount was far beyond what we’d expected.

By today’s standards, ADP didn’t overpay for an acquihire. If anything, it was on the low end. But at the time, these deals weren’t routine—and for us, it was a major outcome. It was also, in a strange way, the moment I finally understood Mody’s real value: not what he knew, but the way he thought about leverage, outcomes, and exits before most of us had the vocabulary for any of it.

---

## 8. Building the ADP Brokerage workstation (FS Partner)

ADP’s urgency wasn’t about consulting revenue. They didn’t need another consulting firm. They needed a **product team**.

ADP Brokerage already had a market data workstation called **FS Partner**. It delivered real-time quotes, news, and front-office functionality to brokers at major financial institutions. The space was competitive—Reuters, Telerate, Quotron, and others—and the differentiation came down to performance, reliability, and the ability to run a modern, multi-application desktop.

That was the problem: the PC operating systems available at the time weren’t really built for what ADP wanted. **MS-DOS** didn’t have true multitasking and windowing. A workstation needed multiple things running at once—quotes, news, messaging, maybe charting—and the desktop had to behave like a *platform*.

ADP had made an unusual choice: they built their workstation on an operating system called **Mondrian**, based on IBM’s **TopView**—IBM’s early attempt to compete with the brand-new Microsoft Windows. TopView never became a market standard. Mondrian, by extension, was clearly a dead end.

When they acquired Multex, it became obvious that if ADP wanted to win long-term, they had to bet on an operating system the market would accept. The question was: which one?

At that moment in time, **Windows was young**, and it wasn’t obvious it would win. Meanwhile IBM was promising something that sounded far more “real” to corporate technologists: **OS/2**. Many people believed IBM would dominate the future the way it dominated the present.

ADP believed it too.

That belief was embedded into our acquisition contract: the deliverables tied to the remaining $4 million were essentially an obligation to build the next-generation FS Partner based on what we’d learned with Multex Quote—only now, rebuilt as a full workstation on **OS/2**.

**George Baird** led the development. Our team delivered the OS/2 version on time—and we delivered it with style.

The only problem was the market.

OS/2 didn’t become the standard people predicted. By the time our product was ready, ADP’s clients didn’t want it. They wanted what they believed their own customers would support—and that was increasingly **Windows**, and in many institutional environments, **UNIX/X-Windows**.

To ADP’s credit, we still got paid the first installment. **Bob Casale** was instrumental in that. He behaved like a gentleman—recognizing that we had delivered what we were asked to deliver, even if the industry had shifted underneath the plan.

But I didn’t want our relationship with ADP to be defined by “we met the contract.” I wanted ADP to get something that actually mattered in the market.

So we did what the contract didn’t explicitly require: we ported the workstation to **Microsoft Windows** and to **UNIX/X-Windows**. When we were done, ADP had a workstation product that could run on whatever operating system the client wanted: Windows, UNIX, and yes—OS/2.

---

## 9. Commercial success of FS Partner

That flexibility changed everything.

FS Partner became a leader in the brokerage workstation community, and by the end of our four-year term, it had captured roughly **70% of the U.S. brokerage workstation market**. We collected the remaining payments.

By then I was a **Senior VP**, working directly for Bob. On paper, I was exactly where someone with my background was “supposed” to land: senior role, major product, market share, momentum.

But personally, I was starting to look for the next challenge—something that felt like *creation*, not continuation.

Bob tried to give me that challenge inside ADP. For a variety of reasons (not worth detouring into here), it didn’t quite happen.

And that’s the point where it makes sense to introduce **Jim Tousignant**.

Jim had been the first salesperson we hired at Multex Systems—probably around our second year. He was young and didn’t have much formal sales experience, but he was a natural. He’d been crucial in our Microsoft relationship and in getting us into conversations with the market data vendors.

After ADP acquired Multex, Jim became one of ADP’s sales executives. One of his biggest accounts was **Merrill Lynch**—likely ADP Brokerage’s largest customer—with something like **15,000 FS Partner workstations** installed.

When Merrill spoke, ADP listened.

---

## 10. The idea that didn’t sound exciting (yet): electronic research distribution

One day Jim came to me with a proposal Merrill had floated to ADP.

This was around 1989—long before the internet became a default distribution channel. Wide-area communications were done through **proprietary networks**, and they were expensive. ADP had built and maintained a network connecting its data centers to client locations in order to deliver real-time market data. Merrill was deeply aware of how valuable that network was.

Merrill wanted to increase the network’s value—and at the same time reduce the cost of delivering information to both internal and external clients.

They had a very specific pain point: **research**.

“Wall Street Research” was produced in massive quantities by Merrill’s analysts—reports on public companies, sectors, markets, instruments. At that time, the output was typically a printed document: often long, sometimes in color, distributed constantly.

Printing and mailing these research packets cost serious money—*tens of millions of dollars a year* for a firm like Merrill. Hundreds of analysts, thousands of companies, and a distribution obligation to institutions all over the country (and beyond). It was industrial-scale paper.

Some smart people in Merrill’s research operations started asking the obvious question:

If ADP already has a network reaching our sites, why can’t we distribute research electronically?

They talked to Jim—ADP’s representative—and Jim immediately saw the opportunity. He came to me to ask whether it was technically feasible.

I thought about it and said yes: technically feasible, absolutely.

But I also told him the truth: it didn’t excite me. Compared to real-time quotes and workstations and all the engineering complexity we’d lived in, “electronic document delivery” sounded… tame.

Jim disagreed. He felt there was something bigger hiding in it.

And for a while, we went back and forth—kicking the idea between us—without realizing we were circling the edge of the next Multex.

### Chapter — 1981: The First PC (Final)

I came to the United States in May of 1980. By then I was working at Golding Industries—my second job in America—doing software development for a textile manufacturing company. The computer I lived inside every day was an IBM mainframe running CICS, an online transaction system that handled everything the business did in real time.

One task in particular stayed with me.

Golding had a manufacturing plant in South Carolina, and they needed invoices printed there—remotely—without someone manually handling tapes or paper in New York. Today that sounds ordinary. Back then it wasn’t. The system didn’t really “support” programming a remote printer the way you’d expect. So I did what you did in those days: I went down to the metal. I wrote a utility at the machine-code level and made it work.

I was proud of it. But I also couldn’t forget how hard it had been just to do something so basic—send words to paper.

Even before I left the USSR, I’d heard rumors of a new kind of technology while listening to Voice of America: *personal computers.* Small enough to sit on a desk. Affordable enough—supposedly—that a person could own one. The idea lodged in my head like a splinter: a real computer that belonged to you.

By the fall of 1981 my wife and I had been working for close to a year. We weren’t making much by American standards, but we had something we hadn’t had before: stability. We lived in a rented apartment in Brooklyn with almost no furniture—just necessities. But compared to what we’d left behind, it felt like freedom.

And that’s when I remembered my promise to myself: I was going to get a PC.

The popular machines then were the Apple II and the TRS-80. IBM had announced its PC, but nobody yet knew it would become *the* standard. I chose it anyway. I was working on IBM systems every day, and I believed—almost instinctively—in IBM’s gravity. If I was going to buy a computer with my own money, it had to be an IBM PC.

The problem was the price.

My system had 64KB of memory. For storage it had two floppy drives, 320KB each. And a dot-matrix printer that—if I remember correctly—printed at about 10 characters per second. By today’s standards it’s almost comical. The Mac I’m writing this story on has 32GB of memory—32,000,000,000 bytes compared to 64,000.

But in 1981 it was a full-blown computer. A programmable machine. A world.

The cost was over $5,000 at the IBM retail store when they opened in New York—over $14,000 in today’s money. My annual salary was around $24,000. I had been in the country barely a year. We had no real savings. Still, I was determined.

So I went to a bank for a personal loan.

They said no—at least, not without a guarantor. My credit history was too short. If someone with strong credit co-signed, they would do it.

I asked a man named Mody Zeidman.

Mody lived in our neighborhood. He volunteered as an English teacher at our synagogue. He was a lawyer—a native New Yorker—with everything I didn’t yet have: a long history in this country, a stable reputation, and the kind of confidence that comes with belonging. At the time I didn’t fully understand what I was asking. In my mind it was just paperwork.

In America, it was trust.

Mody agreed without hesitation.

With Mody’s signature, the bank gave me a $6,000 loan. I went to the IBM store and brought home my computer. I still remember setting it up on the only table we owned.

(There’s a photo from that day. I’m half naked because it was summer, hot, and we didn’t have an air conditioner yet. But we had a computer.)

Once everything was connected and powered up, I started to learn the machine the way I always learned machines: by taking it apart with code.

The software was primitive. There wasn’t even a real text editor—just a line editor. You edited one line at a time. For programming you had BASIC and, if you were brave, assembler for Intel’s 8088.

I decided my first project would be a full-screen text editor, like the one I used on the IBM mainframe at work.

It was harder than I expected. But while building it I realized something that would later become the heart of everything: if I controlled the screen and the keyboard mapping, I didn’t have to stop at English. With some creativity, I could make it write in Russian—or any alphabet I understood. And I could make it go not only left to right, but right to left.

My best friend, Gera Ginzburg, was living in Israel then. He had left the USSR almost a year before me. When I told him what I was building, he immediately said: “Make it support Hebrew. Make it write right to left.”

He was right. And once the idea was spoken out loud, there was no going back.

I brought in Gera in Israel and Igor Saxonov in Brooklyn—someone I’d been introduced to—and the three of us worked nights. We kept pushing the editor until it became something bigger: a multilingual word processor.

Within a year, we had a product that felt unusual for the early IBM PC market.

And then we hit a new problem.

We had built it.

But we had absolutely no idea what to do with it. In the USSR we didn’t know how to start a business. In America, we were about to find out—fast.

---

### Early Days of Marketing a PC Product

Once we had a multilingual word processor that actually worked, we ran straight into a problem that had nothing to do with software.

We didn’t know how to sell it.

Of the three of us, Igor was the most entrepreneurial. He didn’t have a “network” in the American sense of the word—none of us did—but he had initiative and a kind of fearless curiosity. He started calling people, asking questions, turning small connections into meetings. Friends of friends. Acquaintances from the neighborhood. Anyone who might know someone who owned a computer store or knew a businessman who was “in computers.”

That’s how we began to get introduced to the early PC world in Brooklyn—small storefronts, cramped back offices, people learning the business as they went along. We’d bring disks, do demonstrations, talk too much, and listen carefully. Sometimes we were taken seriously. Sometimes we weren’t. Sometimes we were sure we were in the middle of a real business conversation, only to realize later that we were speaking different languages—not Russian and English, but “engineering” and “sales.”

Through this meager chain of introductions, we eventually found our way to the Want brothers and their store in downtown Brooklyn. In those days, a computer store wasn’t a sleek showroom—it was more like a workshop with a cash register. Boxes stacked to the ceiling, machines in various states of assembly, printers chattering in the background, customers asking basic questions that today would seem unbelievable. The Want brothers were practical people. They understood customers. They understood what sold. And they understood immediately that what we had—especially the ability to handle multiple alphabets, and right-to-left—wasn’t just a technical trick. For the right buyer, it was a market.

One introduction led to another. Without going into some details that were, in hindsight, almost hilarious, we stumbled into a man who decided he would build a software company around our product.

He wasn’t a programmer. He wasn’t even from the PC world. He was a sophisticated businessman—a commodities trader—who saw the opportunity before he understood the mechanics. And he was about to learn, the hard way, that early PC software wasn’t like commodities. You couldn’t treat it as a thing you bought and sold and expected to behave by itself. It needed engineering. It needed support. It needed constant improvement.

But in one crucial respect, he was serious: he wanted to buy the product outright.

---

### Selling the Product — “Lock, Stock and Barrel”

By then, Mody Zeidman had become more than the man who co-signed my bank loan. He was the one American in our orbit who could translate this new world for us: contracts, leverage, negotiation, the quiet power of simply knowing how business is done here.

Mody helped us negotiate and represented us through what became a surprisingly convoluted, protracted process. There were terms, conditions, drafts, revisions, and the kind of back-and-forth that feels less like logic and more like endurance—especially when you’re new to the country and still learning how to read between the lines.

In the end we agreed on a deal that, even now, still feels unreal when I say it out loud.

The buyer formed a company specifically for our product and purchased it—and all rights to it—*lock, stock and barrel* for **$600,000**.

Only because of Mody’s help did we get what I believe was a very strong price for that time. We signed the papers and walked away from our creation somewhat stunned by the size of the number. For three recent emigrants who had started from scratch, it didn’t just feel like a business transaction. It felt like proof that we could build something valuable in America.

To close the loop on the word processor: the new company and product were named **World Master**. Apparently, it eventually went public—I suspect on the AIM market, but I’m not sure. What I do know is that it never made the progress it could have, because it didn’t have software engineering support. The man who bought it didn’t engage us to keep developing it. Without the people who understood the code, the product couldn’t evolve the way the market demanded. In time, the company folded.

So our first product didn’t become a long-term commercial success.

But for us personally, it changed everything.

We were equal partners, and each of us walked away with **$200,000**. By then it was **January 1986**—in today’s value, that would be over **$560,000** each. A meaningful amount of money by any standard. For three recent emigrants, it felt enormous.

We felt rich. And in the USSR we didn’t know how to start a business. In America, we were about to find out—fast.

11.	Spin out and founding of Multex Two  It was already 1989, our contract with ADP was successfully completed and I was starting the gradual separation from ADP. Bob Casale was very much a gentleman and supported my efforts. He and I agreed that in return for the Multex’s team continued technical support of FS Partner for the next two years ADP will let us use the existing space and pay a retainer (I think of $2 millions a year) for the next two years. Obviously, this was a very generous separation agreement. Essentially Bob was giving me back my Multex System business and continuing to support it with space and a very material retainer.  I have started getting back into the business I knew well from pre-ADP days of finding clients who we can help develop technical solutions on consulting basis.  One of our first clients was a start-up in the field of medical systems. In today’s terms it would be called a big data vendor. They were building a data repository that they intended to package as an information product for hospitals. Our team was building the technology for this group. Since it was a start up their financing came from a number of VCs. One of these VCs was Euclid Partners. I was doing the presentation of the technology platform we built for this client to Euclid. Euclid was represented by a young associate from, Fred Wilson. Fred was 27 or 28 years old at the time and has just started his career in the VC business. Euclid was his first VC job. As I was doing the presentation Fred, I guess, got interested by the team that was building the technology for the product and asked me what else is my team working on and if we have other products that we are working on. I was still thinking about the Merrill product idea and decided to share it with Fred. He got very excited and said that this concept is very interesting, and would we be interested in getting VC funding for this product. I said, yes, we would be interested in VC funding. That was my first introduction to VCs and the whole idea of VC based business development. I knew nothing about the whole VC concept, but this discussion started me and the Multex team in a very different direction of building a business. This was the starting point of the new Multex, the company that took seven years from the inception to an IPO in 1999, at the pick of the Internet boom of the first generation of Internet based companies and then another four years of running a public company and eventually selling it to Reuters in 2003.

## 11. Spin-out and the founding of Multex II

By 1989, we’d done what we came to ADP to do. The deliverables were complete, FS Partner was real in the market, and my own energy was already drifting toward what came next. The separation from ADP didn’t happen with a dramatic resignation or a slammed door—it was gradual, practical, almost civilized.

A lot of that was because of **Bob Casale**.

Bob was, in every sense that mattered, a gentleman. He didn’t treat my desire to leave as betrayal, and he didn’t try to squeeze every last ounce out of the acquisition on the way out. Instead, we worked out an arrangement that was so generous it almost didn’t feel like corporate America.

Bob and I agreed on this: in return for the Multex team continuing to provide technical support for FS Partner for the next two years, ADP would let us keep using the existing office space and would pay us a retainer—something like **$2 million a year**—during that period.

It wasn’t just a bridge. It was a runway.

In effect, Bob was handing me back the Multex Systems business—reconstituted, stabilized, and funded—and giving me time to rebuild without the usual chaos that comes with starting over.

So I went back to what I knew. Pre-ADP Multex. Find clients with hard problems and build technical solutions for them on a consulting basis.

One of our first clients was a startup in the medical systems world. In today’s language, you’d probably call them a *big data* company. They were building a large data repository and planning to package it as an information product for hospitals. Our team built the underlying technology platform.

Because they were a startup, they were financed by venture capital. One of their VC investors was **Euclid Partners**. At some point I presented the platform we’d built to Euclid—part product demo, part architectural walkthrough, the kind of meeting where you’re not just showing what works, you’re trying to convince someone that the thing will scale and survive.

Euclid’s representative in the room was a young associate named **Fred Wilson**.

Fred was around 27 or 28 at the time, and he was just starting in venture capital. Euclid was his first VC job. He listened closely, asked sharp questions, and—what stood out to me—he seemed interested not only in the technology but in the people behind it.

At the end of the discussion, he asked a question that shifted the entire conversation:

“What else is your team working on? Do you have other products in mind?”

I still had Merrill’s research distribution idea in my head—the one Jim Tousignant had pushed hard, and the one I’d initially dismissed as not exciting enough. But the idea hadn’t gone away. It had been sitting there, quietly, like something unfinished.

So I told Fred about it: the concept of distributing financial research electronically—using existing networks—at a time when printing and mailing research was costing firms like Merrill tens of millions of dollars a year.

Fred’s reaction was immediate. He leaned in.

He said the concept was not only interesting—it was fundable.

Then he asked the question I hadn’t yet learned was a gateway drug to an entirely different life:

“Would you be interested in venture funding for something like that?”

I said yes.

It’s hard to explain how little I understood about venture capital at that moment. I knew nothing about term sheets, valuation, preferences, boards, or what it meant to build a company designed to scale fast. But that conversation was my first real introduction to the VC world—and to the idea that you could build a business around a product and finance growth with outside capital rather than consulting revenue.

That was the starting point of **Multex II**.

The “new Multex” would take seven years from that early conception to an IPO in 1999—at the peak of the first internet boom. Then came four years of operating as a public company. And in 2003, we sold it to **Reuters**.

But the seed of all of that—IPO, public company, exit—was planted in a much smaller moment: a VC associate in his first job asking what else we were building, and me realizing, almost mid-sentence, that maybe the idea I’d been calling “not exciting” was actually the next big thing.

Early prototype, Multex Net  Since the Internet wasn’t available yet, the most important part of building a networking product was to build the network itself. Proprietary IP-based distributed network architecture  When we started to build the product, we built it as a PC/Windows based user interface that through a local network connected to a server running on premises. The server itself would connect trough a frame-relay based TCP/IP wide area network to our central system. This system has run our central repository, a data base that accumulated all of the research documents contributed to us by research providers, that in turn also ran a server connected to a PC/Windows based contribution software also provided by us. So, the whole system had a two-tier star configuration, or a two-level graph. (See figure 1. tbd) We called this version of the product Multex Net, since the proprietary network was arguably the most important part of the product. Technically it worked well, but it had a few business and operational challenges. The first was the cost. In these days the cost of wide area connections was not chip. Plus, the cost of servers, routers and other telecommunication equipment was very substantial. Once it was all built out and you have enough customers it would theoretically be cost effective and provide a great moat against competition. But scaling the build out was very expensive. The other problem, also scalability related is to build out the support organization that would be responsible for equipment installation and support on client premises. The system had to have a critical mass of both providers and consumers to be interesting and cost effective to both sides of the equation. And we had to convince both sides that we will be able to do it. The interesting business dynamic was that in our case competition was one of the most important factors that eventually made us successful.  At that time there was only one company in the market that offered a solution somewhat like what we were attempting to do. So, our entrance into the market was generally cheered and supported by both sides Investment Banks and brokerages, producers of research – the sell-side and the Investment Management firms, the consumers of research – the buy-side. Here are some ways to sharpen this chapter while keeping your intent (product-building and personal education) front and center, plus a few “drop-in” rewrites for key moments.

## Big-picture narrative improvements (without “overdoing” VC)
### 1) Establish a clear spine for the chapter
Right now it reads like a rich set of memories (which is good), but the reader needs a simple through-line. A clean spine could be:

**Multex II = product company → needs capital and scale → network/PDF/Internet inflection → competition forces adoption → near-death moment (Fidelity derailed) → B round lifeline → board power shift → Internet pivot → bubble → IPO runway.**

You can reinforce the spine by adding **1–2 sentence “chapter signposts”** at transitions:
- “This was my first lesson: money changes the company, and it changes you.”
- “The second lesson: technology doesn’t win alone—distribution and market structure do.”
- “The third lesson: your board doesn’t ‘advise’ in a crunch; it decides.”

### 2) Make the “product” feel tangible sooner
You talk about architecture, but we don’t yet *feel* what a user experienced. Add one short paragraph early in “Multex Net” like:
- What the buy-side user saw at 6:30am.
- How research arrived, how it was organized, why it was better than fax/First Call.
- A tiny “day in the life” moment makes the system real.

### 3) Turn a few parts into scenes (not summaries)
Pick 3 “scene anchors” and dramatize them with a room, a line of dialogue, and stakes:
- **The Maiden Lane decision** (your fear vs. Mody’s conviction).
- **Adobe PDF event** (you spot First Call CTO watching).
- **Fidelity deal collapsing** (the day-before-signing whiplash).
- Optional fourth: **the board showdown about Internet**.

Everything else can stay summarized.

### 4) Clarify the cast (and keep names from blurring)
You introduce many names fast. A light trick: **re-attach roles** the second time they appear:
- “Fred (still learning VC himself, but ahead of me by two turns)…”
- “Milton Pappas, Fred’s senior partner—older, quieter, the kind of authority you don’t question.”

### 5) Tighten the tech sections to “why it mattered”
Your architecture description is strong but could be trimmed by 25–40% and tied more explicitly to consequences:
- expensive to scale
- hard to install/support
- created moat *if* you survived long enough
That keeps the reader oriented even if they aren’t technical.
