### Multex II

Multex II was a very different business than Multex I. Multex I was, at its core, a services company. The “service” was a way to make a living—for me and for the people who depended on the company for a paycheck—while I kept trying to build something more scalable. I had always dreamed about building products, but in those early years I didn’t really know a practical path to do it. I assumed you either had revenue or you didn’t have a business.

From my first meeting with Fred, I realized there was another path—if you could get venture capitalists interested enough to fund the effort. Fred made it sound straightforward. I was just beginning to learn what the process actually involves and how much of it is its own discipline. By the time Multex went public, I had a full education in what it really means to build a VC-backed company. We ultimately raised more than $50 million across multiple rounds—A through F, if I remember correctly—and I pitched and negotiated with a large number of investors along the way.

But I don’t want this story to become a venture-capital memoir. The real story is my experience of building a product business, and how that experience educated me—about leadership, markets, decision-making, and what it means to be a businessman and an entrepreneur. Along the way, it also taught me about life in America—New York’s version of it, to be more precise.

A lot of my early “VC education” was facilitated by Fred. He was learning the discipline himself, but he was generous in sharing what he knew and what he was observing. Over time, I learned to trust him and to rely on his advice and judgment. I have now known Fred for almost 35 years—nearly the span of both our careers. Today he is a close friend, a colleague, and, of course, a very successful and famous VC. But that’s 35 years later. In the early days, he was simply the person who helped me understand how this world worked.

---

## 1. Series A: Euclid Partners

After our first meeting, Fred introduced me to the firm and, more importantly, to Milton Pappas—his senior partner and mentor. Milton was from a different generation, almost my parents’ generation, but over the years I came to know and appreciate him. In his own way, and alongside Fred, he helped me navigate the venture world: how investors think, what questions matter, and what “support” really means once money is on the table.

The first round—Series A, led by Euclid Partners—was one of the most difficult, as it often is. Mody and I each committed $100,000 to demonstrate personal conviction and alignment. Euclid, after substantial due diligence, invested about $1 million. So, if I remember correctly, the round was roughly $1.2 million total: $200,000 from Mody and me, and the rest from Euclid.

That financing started us down two paths at once: Multex’s path toward becoming a venture-backed company, and my personal path toward learning how to build and run a product-based business at scale.

One of the first practical things we did—once the money was actually in the bank—was look for office space. Our time at ADP was coming to an end, and our contract with them was expiring. We needed a home of our own.

We found a sublet in the financial district: **32 Maiden Lane**, directly across from the Federal Reserve. It was fully furnished and had room for about 50 people. At the time, we had just over 20. My first reaction was anxiety. It felt like too much space, too much commitment, and too much overhead for a company still finding its footing.

But the price was very low even by the standards of that era—about $13 per square foot—and Mody convinced me to take it. It turned out to be a very smart decision. We filled that space, I think, in less than a year. And from that point on, downtown Manhattan became our preferred home for much of the next decade.

With the company housed and funded, we could focus fully on the product.

---

## 2. Early prototype: Multex Net

In the early 1990s, before the Internet became mainstream, a “networking product” often meant you had to build the network itself. We also had to choose a portable document format robust enough for electronic delivery of research documents.

Luck is always part of any successful business. Multex benefited from two pieces of luck without which we might not have succeeded at all. The first was the Internet eventually becoming a mainstream utility. The second was the announcement—and then the rapid proliferation—of **PDF** as a portable document format.

Before either of those forces fully played out, we built an early system that we called **Multex Net**, because the proprietary network was arguably the most important part of the product.

---

## 3. A proprietary, IP-based distributed network architecture

The first iteration of Multex Net was designed as a Windows/PC user interface running on the client desktop, connected through a local network to an on-premises server. That server connected via a frame-relay based TCP/IP wide area network to our central system. Our central system maintained a repository and database of research documents. On the contributor side, research providers ran a server that connected to a Windows/PC-based contribution application we supplied. In effect, the system had a two-tier star configuration—a two-level graph.

Technically, it worked well. Business-wise and operationally, it came with serious challenges.

First, it was expensive. Wide-area connectivity was not cheap in those days, and the cost of servers, routers, and telecom equipment added up quickly. If you managed to build enough scale, the economics could become compelling—and the network could become a meaningful moat. But getting to that point required substantial capital.

Second, it created a support and deployment burden. We needed people who could install and support equipment at client sites. Scaling that kind of field operation is always hard.

Nevertheless, with Euclid’s initial investment, we got the system off the ground and began installing early adopter clients on both ends: research providers and institutional investors. Naturally, this introduced another classic problem of two-sided networks: you need a critical mass of providers and consumers for either side to see value. And you have to convince both sides you can get there.

In our case, one factor helped more than anything else: competition.

---

## 4. The market’s appetite for a competitor: First Call

At that time there was essentially one company offering something in the same direction: **First Call**, part of **Thomson Financial**. Their technology was inferior and limited. They delivered only a subset of research—“morning notes”—in text format, via a broadcast system. Once delivered, the information could not be easily changed, and it was not searchable historically. It was, in essence, a research newswire.

But First Call was unique in offering any electronic stream of research at all, and because it was effectively a monopoly, it benefited enormously. It charged both contributors and consumers high prices, and both sides—powerful institutions on the sell-side and the buy-side—hated being beholden to an arrogant monopoly.

That’s why our appearance on the horizon created an unusually supportive reaction. The market wanted a legitimate competitor. Both investment banks and brokerages (the producers of research, the sell-side) and investment management firms (the consumers, the buy-side) wanted a second player to exist.

Throughout our existence, this dynamic helped us. The market generally perceived us as the technologically advanced, nimble, flexible “good guys,” and First Call as the retrograde, inflexible “bad guys.” But competing with a large, financially powerful incumbent was never easy. At times they nearly killed us.

One of the most important episodes began in the summer of 1993.

---

## 5. Adobe and the announcement of PDF

We first ran into First Call directly at the Adobe announcement of PDF, held in New York in one of the big hotels. By then, we already had an early version of Multex Net running—at least good enough to demonstrate.

Jim somehow got us invited to present as one of the early adopters of PDF technology, alongside **Dr. John Warnock**, Adobe’s co-founder. We used an early beta version of the PDF reader in our product.

Sitting in the audience, not far from me, was the CTO of First Call with several colleagues. They watched our presentation closely. It was obvious they were concerned we were moving into their territory.

Shortly afterward we learned that First Call was working on a product that would compete directly with ours.

About a year later, as we started to make early progress, we had major firms adopting on both sides. On the sell-side, we had Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs. On the buy-side, we had T. Rowe Price, Prudential, and several others. We were still early, still fragile—but clearly no longer theoretical.

That’s when Fidelity entered the picture.

---

## 6. Fidelity’s acquisition offer—and how it was derailed

Fidelity Investments was very interested in our product. They were one of the more technologically advanced firms in the industry and also one of the more acquisitive. They began to consider acquiring Multex.

The timing was perfect and, for me personally, compelling. Fidelity offered **$20 million** for the company and proposed to continue funding and resourcing the development of the product. Given Fidelity’s influence, our hardest problem—getting the sell-side firms to contribute research—would become much easier. With enough content from the sell-side, the value to the buy-side would increase dramatically. And because we were still dependent on a proprietary network and needed significant capital to roll it out, Fidelity’s backing mattered.

We went through extensive due diligence. We met Fidelity’s senior management, including **Ned Johnson**, who was the CEO at the time. Everything looked good. In fact, we were one day away from signing the definitive agreement.

Then we received notice that First Call had filed a patent case against us, claiming “prior art” in their technology versus ours.

As it eventually became clear, the claim was baseless. First Call did not even have a comparable product when we were already publicly demonstrating ours. But the lawsuit didn’t have to be right to be effective. It only needed to introduce uncertainty and risk.

Fidelity walked away. The deal was never consummated. And suddenly we had almost no funds to continue development.

We were very close to shutting the company down.

Fred and I immediately began contacting potential investors. One thing that helped keep us credible during that period was that we had completed a deal with Bloomberg Financial to redistribute our research database to their customers. We had a similar agreement with Reuters already. While neither deal materially contributed to revenue at that stage, having both of the major market data vendors aligned with us mattered.

Eventually, we put together the next round.

---

## 7. Series B: a lifeline

We managed to close a Series B round. The main new investor was **AT&T Ventures**, and the partner who led the investment and joined our board was **Alessandro Piol**. I don’t recall whether there were other new investors beyond Euclid continuing to participate, but that round allowed us to keep operating and keep building.

---

## 8. Subsequent raises: Softbank, Chase Capital—and the changing balance of power

Over the next year or two, we raised additional capital from **Softbank** and **Chase Ventures**.

Softbank was represented by **Charley Lax**, who joined our board. Softbank is famous today, but at that time it was much smaller. Through the relationship, I met several of their partners and executives, including **Masayoshi Son**—though that happened later, after we were public, when I traveled to Japan for the opening of Multex Investor Japan, a joint venture with Reuters.

Chase Ventures was represented by **Bob Greene**, who also joined our board.

By this stage, the combined VCs held majority control of the equity, and their influence over the strategic and technical direction of the company became material. This was another lesson I had to learn: raising capital is not only about cash—it is also about governance.

Around the middle of 1995, this became impossible to ignore.

---

## 9. The Internet pivot: founder instinct versus investor urgency

Sometime in mid-1995, we had a board meeting that turned into a heated debate. Our product architecture had been designed in 1993, before browsers and consumer Internet access were commonplace. Even though we were using TCP/IP, we were delivering over a proprietary frame-relay network that guaranteed delivery and throughput—but was expensive.

To continue building and scaling that proprietary network would require significant investment. At the same time, excitement about the Internet was accelerating quickly. Venture capitalists are often the first to get excited, and my investors were no exception. They advocated aggressively that we migrate to Internet delivery rather than continue building a private network.

I was excited too, but I was also wary. Dial-up speeds were slow. Corporate security teams were cautious, sometimes paranoid. Browsers were primitive. I worried that we would lose reliability and the user experience, and that we would damage trust with the very clients we were trying to win.

The VCs were adamant—so adamant that the conversation included the implicit message every founder eventually learns to recognize: if you refuse, you can be replaced.

The debate went on for months. Eventually we reached a compromise: we would build an Internet/browser-based version of the product while continuing to offer a dedicated network option for clients who needed it.

In practice, the Internet adoption curve surprised all of us. Before long, the only version we were selling was the browser-based one. Still, some users loved the more dynamic interface of the original system, and we eventually migrated that experience to an Internet-connected version with an active desktop front end. Today it’s common to have both a browser version and a native desktop app. At the time, it was forward-looking—and it helped us.

The Internet changed almost everything about our business:

1. **Cost structure:** If clients had decent Internet access, they could reach us simply by going to a URL. Many infrastructure costs that had been fundamental to Multex Net effectively vanished.  
2. **Support and operations:** We no longer had to install and support as much hardware on client premises. Our operational burden dropped dramatically.  
3. **Market excitement and acceptance:** Being perceived as an “Internet company” became a tailwind in itself.  
4. **IPO feasibility:** The Internet created not just a technical platform, but a capital-market moment.

That moment soon became a mania.

---

## 10. The Internet bubble and the road to the IPO

Netscape went public on August 9, 1995, barely a year after being founded. That IPO was a signal flare. It marked the beginning of what became the Internet bubble.

Suddenly, companies with “.com” in the name were treated as if the business model didn’t matter. Many that had no right even to be funded went public. We were swept up in that excitement too.

By 1998–1999, we had built real industry recognition and reached approximately **$20 million** in revenue. We were not yet profitable, but we were growing quickly—close to 100% annually. Compared to many “Internet companies” going public at the time, we were a serious business.

Because our market was what would now be called FinTech—then described more as a “vertical” market rather than a consumer phenomenon—we were not the most fashionable IPO candidate. But investment banks were eager to win mandates, and we were courted heavily.

Eventually we selected three to prepare us for an IPO, in order of priority:
1. **Robertson Stephens** (San Francisco-based specialty investment bank)  
2. **CIBC Oppenheimer** (New York-based)  
3. **Dain Rauscher Wessels** (Midwest-based)

Even though I had run the business for more than four years by then and raised multiple rounds of capital, I was still naïve about what an IPO truly demands. One of my VC investors suggested I hire a private coach to prepare me for the roadshow.

It turned out to be an excellent idea.

My coach was a woman in her sixties who smoked like a chimney. She was tough, direct, and highly effective. She took me clothes shopping, taught me how to stand and speak with confidence, how to stay concise, how to answer questions without wandering, and how to project credibility in a room full of skeptics whose job was to find weakness.

I remember that period with genuine fondness. I was preparing to present Multex to the public markets—but in a deeper sense, I was preparing to become a different kind of CEO than the one who had started by selling services just to keep the lights on.

A few different things can be true at the same time: Multex “failed” in the sense that it did not remain an independent, enduring public company; but it also “succeeded” in building a real product business, reaching meaningful scale, and becoming valuable enough to be acquired. What happened—and why it didn’t last as a standalone company—usually comes down to a combination of market timing, dependence on external platforms/customers, and what the post-bubble public markets demanded.

Since you’re asking generally, here are the most plausible (and memoir-useful) causes to frame it. If you confirm the actual endpoint (acquired by Reuters? folded into Thomson/First Call? delisted? bankrupt?), I can tailor this to the exact facts.

## What happened (typical Multex arc)
1. **Rapid growth into the late-1990s bubble.**  
   The Internet transition lowered distribution costs and increased adoption, and the market rewarded “Internet-enabled” infrastructure companies with high valuations.

2. **IPO momentum met a new reality post-2000.**  
   After the bubble broke, public investors stopped paying for growth alone and started demanding profitability, predictability, and defensible margins.

3. **Industry consolidation accelerated.**  
   Financial information is a scale game. Big incumbents (Reuters, Thomson, Bloomberg) already owned distribution, enterprise contracts, and workflows. Over time they tend to absorb point solutions—even good ones—because customers prefer fewer vendors and integrated platforms.

4. **Multex became strategically valuable, but strategically exposed.**  
   If your content came from sell-side contributors and your users were buy-side institutions, then you were in the middle of two powerful constituencies. That position is valuable, but it also means:
   - contributors can threaten to withhold content or demand better economics,
   - big distributors can replicate features or squeeze you on distribution,
   - customers can use you as leverage in pricing negotiations with bigger vendors.

That combination often ends not with a dramatic “failure,” but with a forced choice: **sell, merge, or get slowly compressed.**

## Why it failed (root causes that make sense in a memoir)
### 1) The moat moved: infrastructure advantage became temporary
Multex Net’s early moat was partly technical (network + delivery). Once the Internet became the standard transport and PDF became ubiquitous, **delivery stopped being scarce**. The advantage shifted from “we can deliver it” to:
- “we own the workflow”
- “we own the desktop”
- “we bundle it with terminals/data”
That favored Bloomberg/Reuters/Thomson.

### 2) Two-sided marketplace dynamics never fully go away
Even with scale, you’re always balancing:
- sell-side economics and compliance concerns,
- buy-side willingness to pay,
- and the platform in the middle trying to capture value.
If either side sees you as replaceable—or sees your fees as a tax—they push back hard.

### 3) The public markets changed what “good” looked like
Post-bubble, a $20M revenue company growing fast but still investing heavily could be punished. If the market demands profitability and you still need to spend to:
- acquire/retain content partners,
- build product features to keep up with platforms,
- support enterprise clients,
then you can get trapped: **cut costs and stall growth, or spend and miss earnings**.

### 4) Distribution is destiny in financial information
Even if the product is better, incumbents have:
- existing enterprise relationships,
- procurement leverage,
- bundled pricing,
- and default presence on the trader/investor desktop.
A standalone product company can win—briefly—but long-term independence is hard unless you become the platform.

### 5) Competitive pressure can turn from “tailwind” to “gravity”
Early on, the market wanted you to exist to discipline First Call’s pricing—so they supported you. But once you became established, those same institutions had incentives to:
- commoditize the service,
- negotiate pricing down,
- treat you as interchangeable infrastructure.

## The most compelling way to tell it in Multex II
For memoir purposes, the cleanest framing is not “we failed,” but:

> “We built something real, but the industry we served rewards scale and integration more than it rewards standalone innovation.”

That lets you keep the dignity of the accomplishment while still explaining the outcome.

Shortly after that we discovered First Call was working on a product that would provide functionality directly competitive to ours.

About a year later, as we made early progress in the market, we already had several important contributors and users. These were big firms—our early supporters and adopters. On the sell-side we had **Merrill Lynch** and **Goldman Sachs**. On the buy-side we had **T. Rowe Price**, **Prudential**, and others.

---

### Fidelity’s Acquisition Offer—Derailed

Fidelity Investments was very interested in our product as well. They were one of the more technologically advanced firms, and one of the most acquisitive in technology. They began to consider acquiring Multex.

At that point we had mostly used up the first round and were evaluating our next step. Fidelity’s interest was timely and, for me personally, financially meaningful. They offered **$20 million** for the company and proposed to provide continuing funding and resources so we could keep building the product.

Given Fidelity’s influence in the market, our most difficult task—getting sell-side firms to contribute their research—would become much less of an issue. With critical mass of content from the sell-side, the value of the product to the buy-side would increase dramatically.

Also, because we were still running on a proprietary network and needed significant funding to roll it out, Fidelity’s financial backing was crucial.

We went through extensive due diligence. We met with senior management at Fidelity, including **Ned Johnson**, the CEO at the time. Everything looked good. In fact, we were just a day away from signing the definitive agreement.

That’s when we received notification that First Call had started a patent case against us, claiming “prior art” in their technology versus ours.

As it eventually turned out, it was completely bogus. We clearly had prior art: First Call didn’t even have a product when we were already publicly demonstrating ours. But the filing itself was enough to scare off Fidelity. The deal was never consummated.

Suddenly we had almost no funds to continue development. We were very close to shutting the company down.

Fred and I immediately started contacting potential investors. One lifesaving factor at that point was that we had completed a deal with **Bloomberg Financial** to become a redistributor of our research database to their customers. We already had a similar deal signed with **Reuters**, and adding the other major market data vendor was important, even though financially neither deal materially contributed to revenue at that stage.

---

### Series B: AT&T Ventures

We eventually managed to pull together the next round. The main new investor was **AT&T Ventures**, and the partner who led the investment—and became a board member—was **Alessandro Piol**.

I don’t remember whether we had other new investors in that round beyond Euclid Partners continuing to participate. But once the round closed, we were able to continue operations.

---

### Subsequent Raises: Softbank and Chase Ventures

Over the next year or two, we raised additional capital from **Softbank** and **Chase Ventures**.

Softbank is, of course, a famous investment house, but at the time it was much smaller. They were represented by **Charley Lax**, who joined our board. Even though Multex wasn’t one of their famous mega-investments, as one of their portfolio companies I met several partners and executives, including the famous **Masayoshi Son**. That happened much later, after we were already public, when I was in Japan for the opening of **Multex Investor Japan**, a joint venture with Reuters.

Chase Ventures was represented by **Bob Greene**, who also joined our board of directors.

By this point, the combined VCs held majority control of the equity in the company, so their influence on the business and technical direction became very important.

---

### Diverging Views: The Internet Debate

One key event I remember from that period—sometime in the middle of 1995—was a discussion that became more like a heated debate at a board meeting.

The first version of our product had been built around 1993, when the Internet and the browser were not yet as commonplace as they would soon become. Even though we used a TCP/IP network, the system relied on a proprietary frame-relay network, which guaranteed delivery and throughput but was very expensive. To build it out we needed substantial investment.

By then, excitement around the Internet was reaching a very high level, as often happens when a new technology trend takes off. VCs tend to be the first to get excited. My investors were advocating very aggressively that we migrate to Internet delivery instead of continuing with a proprietary private network.

Even though I was equally excited about what the Internet could become, I also recognized the practical limitations at that time. Most connections were dial-up. Corporate clients were reluctant and cautious about adopting what they viewed as an insecure and very slow Internet. And given the primitive capabilities of early browsers, I believed our chances of delivering a robust, information-heavy product over the Internet were slim.

The investors were adamant—so adamant that they intimated that if I wouldn’t agree, they would fire me as CEO.

The debate went back and forth for months. Eventually we settled on a compromise: we would implement an Internet/browser-based version of the product, but continue to offer both options—a dedicated network and an Internet version.

We operated that way for a while, but the speed of Internet adoption surprised all of us. Before long, the only version of the product we offered was the Internet/browser-based version.

At the same time, we had a group of users who loved the dynamic interface of the older version. We ended up migrating that proprietary interface to the Internet so we could offer an Internet-connected version with an active desktop front end. Today this type of approach is common—many applications have both a browser version and a native desktop app. At the time, it proved to be forward-looking.

The Internet changed almost everything for us.

First, it changed the **cost structure**. Instead of paying for infrastructure and operations on a proprietary network, many of those costs effectively disappeared. If clients had a decent Internet connection, all they had to do to access our service was point their browser to our URL.

Second, it reduced our **support and operational burden**. We no longer had to install and support as much equipment on client premises, and the complexity on our side dropped dramatically.

Third, it changed **market perception**. The excitement around the Internet and the opportunities it represented reached such a peak that any company considered an “Internet company”—especially with a “.com” in the name—became golden.

---

### The Internet Bubble

Suddenly, young Internet companies began to go public. Netscape IPO’d on August 9, 1995, only a year after being founded. That was really the beginning of the Internet bubble.

I don’t think Netscape had meaningful revenue at that point. And after that, it often didn’t matter whether a company had a reasonable business model or even a plan. Many companies that didn’t deserve to be funded went public.

Naturally, we were swept up in the excitement.

By 1998–1999 we had already established a solid name in the industry and reached revenue of approximately **$20 million**. We were not yet profitable, but we were growing at a good rate—probably close to 100% annually. Compared to many so-called Internet companies at the time, we were a reasonable candidate for an IPO within a year or two.

But because of the excitement—and pressure from investors—we decided to take advantage of momentum and go public while the market was hot. And it was super-hot.

---

### Building Up to the IPO

Because our market was what today would be called FinTech—but at the time was considered a “vertical” market rather than a consumer market, which was more fashionable—we were not viewed as the most favorable IPO candidate. Nevertheless, investment banks were eager to secure potential IPO targets and courted us aggressively.

Eventually we selected three firms to prepare us for an IPO, in order of priority:

1. **Robertson Stephens**, a San Francisco-based specialty investment bank  
2. **CIBC Oppenheimer**, a New York-based investment bank  
3. **Dain Rauscher Wessels**, a Midwest-based investment bank  

Even though I had been running the business for over four years by then and had raised significant VC capital, I was still naïve about IPOs and what the process really demanded. Some of my VC investors suggested that I hire a private instructor to educate me and prepare me for the roadshow.

It turned out to be a very good and interesting experience. My coach was a woman in her sixties, and she smoked like a chimney. But she was excellent. She took me clothes shopping, worked with me on being comfortable in front of an audience, taught me how to make a concise, to-the-point presentation, and drilled me on many other skills that turned out to be essential for a CEO preparing to face public markets.

Overall, I remember that preparation period with real fondness. It wasn’t only about going public. It was part of my continuing education—learning how to represent the company, the product, and the story in a way that investors, analysts, and the market could understand.

## Multex II

Multex II was a very different business than Multex I. Multex I was primarily a service business. The service work was a means to provide a living for me and my employees. Even then, I was always dreaming about building products, but I didn’t really know there were other options. I thought you either had enough revenue to fund your growth, or you didn’t have a business.

From my first meeting with Fred, I realized there was another path—if you could get venture capitalists interested in supporting your efforts. At that first meeting, Fred made it sound easy. I was just starting to learn what “easy” really meant.

The truth is, raising VC money is its own story. By the time Multex went public, I had a real education in what it means to build a VC-backed company. Eventually we raised more than $50 million in five or six rounds—A through F, if I remember correctly—and I pitched to, negotiated with, and answered to a substantial number of investors.

Still, I don’t want this chapter to overdo the venture-capital angle. I want it to be about my experience building a product business and the education I received in the process—about leadership, decision-making, markets, and what it means to be a businessman and an entrepreneur. Along the way I was also learning about life in America—New York’s version of it, to be more precise.

Most of my early VC education was facilitated by Fred. He was learning the discipline himself, but he was generous in sharing what he knew and what he was learning. Over time, I learned to trust him and rely on his advice and judgment. I have known Fred now for almost 35 years—nearly the span of both our careers. Today he is a close friend and colleague, and a very successful and well-known VC. But that’s decades later. Back then, he was the person helping me understand a world I didn’t yet speak fluently.

### Series A: Euclid Partners

After our first meeting, Fred introduced me to the rest of the firm and, more importantly, to Milton Pappas, his senior partner and mentor. Milton was from a different generation—almost my parents’ generation—but I came to know and appreciate him. In his own way, he helped me learn how VCs think and how to survive in their ecosystem.

Our Series A round, led by Euclid Partners with Fred, was one of the hardest—like most first rounds. Mody and I each committed $100,000 to show personal dedication. Euclid, after extensive due diligence, invested about $1 million. If I remember correctly, the round totaled roughly $1.2 million, with $200,000 from Mody and me and Euclid covering the rest.

That money started Multex on the path to becoming a VC-backed product company. It also started me on a personal journey toward building and running what would become one of the early Internet-based public companies.

Once the initial financing was in our bank account, one of the first things we did was look for space. Our arrangement with ADP was coming to an end, and our contract with them was expiring. We needed an office we controlled.

We sublet space in the financial district of lower Manhattan, downtown—a location that would become our favorite for much of the next decade. The address was 32 Maiden Lane, directly across from the Federal Reserve. The office was fully furnished and had room for about 50 people. At the time we had just over 20, and my first reaction was worry. It felt like far too much space for a company still learning to walk.

But the rent was remarkably low—about $13 per square foot—and Mody convinced me to take it. In less than a year, we filled the space. That decision was an early reminder that a product company has to think ahead of its current footprint.

### Multex Net: Building the Network Before the Internet

The first iteration of our product was built at a time when the Internet was not yet a practical delivery platform for business-critical systems. In those days, if you were building a networking product, you often had to build the network itself. Another major challenge was choosing a portable document format that could support the electronic delivery of research.

Luck is always part of any successful business. Multex had two lucky breaks without which we might not have succeeded. The first was the Internet becoming mainstream. The second was the announcement—and eventual proliferation—of PDF as a portable document format.

Before either force fully reshaped the world, we built what we called Multex Net. The “Net” was not a marketing flourish. The proprietary network was arguably the most important part of the product.

### A Proprietary, IP-Based Distributed Network Architecture

We built Multex Net as a Windows/PC-based user interface that connected over a local network to a server running on the client’s premises. That server connected through a frame-relay based TCP/IP wide-area network to our central system. Our central system ran the central repository—a database that accumulated all the research documents contributed to us by research providers. Those providers, in turn, ran a server connected to a Windows/PC-based contribution application we supplied.

The whole system had a two-tier star configuration, essentially a two-level graph. (See Figure 1, TBD.) Technically, it worked. But it created serious business and operational challenges.

The first was cost. Wide-area connections were not cheap, and neither was the hardware—servers, routers, and telecommunications equipment. In theory, if you built enough scale, it could become cost-effective and form a moat. In practice, scaling the build-out required significant capital.

The second challenge was support. To install and maintain equipment at client sites, you need an organization built for deployment and field support. That kind of operational burden can grow quickly and become a limiting factor.

Still, with Euclid’s initial investment, we got the system off the ground and started installing early adopter clients—both research providers and institutional investors.

We also faced a classic two-sided-market problem: the system needed a critical mass of both providers and consumers to be valuable to either side. And we had to convince both sides that we could reach that critical mass.

In our case, one of the most important forces that helped us get there was the presence of a competitor.

### First Call: The Monopoly the Market Resented

At the time, there was only one company offering something even somewhat similar to what we were trying to build: First Call, part of Thomson Financial.

Their technology was inferior and limited. They delivered only a small subset of research—“morning notes”—in text format through a broadcast system. It was essentially a broadcast of the snippets that research organizations submitted in the morning. Once delivered, that information could not be changed, and there was no meaningful historical review. And of course, morning notes were only a small fraction of what research departments actually produced.

But First Call had one crucial advantage: it was unique. It offered an electronic stream of research, effectively a research newswire, and it enjoyed the benefits of monopoly status. It charged both contributors and consumers very high prices, and both sides—powerful financial institutions—resented being beholden to a company that behaved like an arrogant monopoly.

That’s why, when we appeared, many firms didn’t just show interest—they wanted us to succeed. The market wanted a legitimate competitor.

Our arrival was generally welcomed by investment banks and brokerages (the producers of research, the sell-side) and by investment management firms (the consumers of research, the buy-side). Throughout our existence, that dynamic helped us. The market tended to see us as technologically advanced, nimble, and flexible—the “good guys”—and First Call as retrograde and inflexible—the “bad guys.”

Of course, competing against a large, well-funded incumbent was never easy. At times they nearly killed us. One of the most memorable sequences started in the summer of 1993.
